questions.clue: In 1999, this U.S. Women's Soccer player scored the winning penalty kick to secure the World Cup against China at the Rose Bowl.
In 2004, this baseball team broke an 86-year-old 'curse' by winning the World Series, coming back from a 3-0 deficit against the New York Yankees in the ALCS.
Known as the 'Shot Heard 'Round the World,' this player's home run sent the New York Giants to the 1951 World Series.
In an ice hockey game during the 1980 Winter Olympics, the U.S. team achieved this 'Miracle on Ice,' defeating a seemingly unbeatable Soviet Union team.
questions.answer: United States victory over Soviet Union

questions.clue: In the 1997 Masters Tournament, this golfer won by a record 12 strokes, marking an iconic moment as he became the tournament's youngest-ever winner at age 21.

categories.name: World Capitals: Off the Beaten Path

questions.clue: For 200 points: Known for its green spaces and rugby culture, this capital of New Zealand hosted the 2011 Rugby World Cup final.
For 400 points: Sports fans in this Bolivian capital can enjoy watching matches at the highest professional stadium in the world.
For 600 points: This Central Asian capital boasts a striking Soviet-era circus building, attracting acrobatic enthusiasts.
For 800 points: The capital of Namibia, known for its German colonial architecture, hosts an annual cycling event that draws international competitors.
For 1000 points: Famous for its off-road motor racing, this Mauritanian capital is a key stopover on the winding routes of the Dakar Rally.
This element is essential for strong bones and is often found in milk.
The chemical symbol for this element, crucial for muscle function, is 'K'.
Like baseball players, these metals on the periodic table are known for their abilities to conduct electricity.
These molecules, known for their support in muscle building, are made of chains of amino acids.
The process in which a liquid absorbs enough heat to become a gas, similar to how athletes 'vaporize' calories during exercise.
For a more dramatic sports highlight, the NFL might choose to use the bombastic opening known as 'Ode to Joy' from this composer's 9th Symphony.
The FIFA World Cup theme uses elements from this Bohemian composer's Symphony No. 9, commonly known as the 'New World Symphony'.
Just like a tactical shift in soccer, this composer's 12-tone technique altered the 'rules' of melody composition.
Much like a game-changing strategy, this Russian composer's 'Rite of Spring' altered ballet with its avant-garde style and caused a riot at its 1913 premiere.
This minimalist composer used phasing techniques in works like 'It's Gonna Rain', similar to maintaining a rhythm in a marathon.
This ancient civilization built pyramids as burial places for their pharaohs, much like modern sports stadiums honor champions.
The Mesoamerican ballgame, played by this civilization, was one of the world's oldest team sports, predating even the Olympics.
This ancient civilization, known for its city-state Sparta, introduced the concept of athletic competition as training for war.
In the Andes, this civilization built terraced mountainsides, similar to how modern sports venues maximize seating space.
This civilization's chariot races in the Circus Maximus were extravagant events akin to today's major sporting spectacles.

final.clue: As of 2023, this athlete holds the record for the most Olympic gold medals won by a single individual, with 23 golds.
